1110637967838724096.text:
1/ With today's launch of @messaricrypto's "Real 10 Volumes", we wanted to highlight how important it is that the industry start challenging (or ignoring) @CoinMarketCap as a source of data.

Obviously, we love our data. But this is about more than our competitive positioning.

1110535139606626306.text:
One reason we started the @MessariCrypto registry was to get better at tracking "real" circulating supply.

Here are projected supply curves for the first 15 registry participants.

(We're also releasing projections for the top 50 assets later today. )

https://messari.io/c/supply-curves pic.twitter.com/Ay6S1rPMaU

1110637992052432897.text:
fin/ Use Messari. Don't use Messari. Not the point.

We like our new "Real 10 Volumes." But other data vendors are also kicking ass. The market would do well to support those alternatives, or light a fire under the ass of the CMC team.

The industry will be better for it.

1110637991280721920.text:
16/ If you're gauging whether to trust CMC and its data integrity upgrades, you should consider:

+ They've done little to improve data methods in 18 mos, with a massive warchest
+ They've profited from unethical advertisers
+ There are MANY superior options for crypto data today

1110637989493919745.text:
15/ It's worth asking: 

Can you trust a company that turned a blind eye to ads for blatant ponzi's, specious cloud mining services, and "guaranteed daily returns!" products?

I'll leave that to you to judge. I will say I shut down those types of ads on day one running @coindesk.

1110637986998300674.text:
14/ On this point, I think industry pros would do well to look at historical intent. And this is where the company's questionable ad policies come back around.

CMC was built on the back of ICO mania, and a number of scams that funded them for *months.* (image h/t @nic__carter):pic.twitter.com/0XlI0lyxUL

1110637985727422464.text:
13/ So we don't know *why* the company has been so slow to adjust their methodologies. Perhaps it's some combination of a, b, c.

Doesn't really matter. 

What matters is this:

Can third parties trust CMC to make the necessary fixes in a timely manner?

1110637981210214401.text:
12/ Here's the loaded one, c.

This thesis says the team is not up to the task ahead when it comes to professionalizing the business and its data standards.

Though hard to believe the scrappy market leader with a massive warchest can't execute again given its massive head start.

1110637980467777539.text:
11/ There's a good argument for b, too.

One likely issue is that CMC hasn't been seriously challenged yet. (Also, I'd likely work fewer hours if I experienced the tremendous wealth generation CMC did in the 2017 run up.)

If b, that's a concern for customers.

1110637979868061699.text:
10/ There's a good argument for a.

CMC was (amazingly) built out of a Queens apartment...by a small team. They undoubtedly faced scaling challenges, and had to build out the team to keep up with inbound interest.

But $100 million can get you good people.

1110637979045896193.text:
9/ CMC did not use their leverage to improve data quality. Why? 

Three options:

a) The team has been overwhelmed.
b) The team is complacent.
c) The team is not up to the task ahead.

Let's look at these one at a time.

1110637978425151489.text:
8/ BUT you'd think that in the past 18 months, CMC would have iterated significantly on their data methodologies, and used their market clout and war chest to pressure token teams / exchanges to report cleaner data.

They're the only data aggregator with that type of leverage.

1110637977716359168.text:
7/ Again, I want to stress that many of these issues are VERY difficult to solve for. We haven't figured them all out yet, either.

How do you get token teams and exchanges to accurately report treasury and true volume info absent consistent global regs / self-regs?

1110637975203971073.text:
6/ Trading volumes are inflated by 20-50x. These are displayed "as reported."

This could impact VWAP calculations for pricing. Indeed, CMC consistently reports inflated prices vs. us, CryptoCompare, Nomics, and CoinCap. (We use CoinCap and Kaiko as data redundancies.)pic.twitter.com/5mz9bbuk2F

1110637972653780993.text:
5/ CMC, despite a rumored $100 million in (high-margin!!!) revenue in 2017, has done next to nothing to work on data standards in the past 18 months.

Circulating supply is delivered "as reported" from token teams. That inflates market cap figures which power indices erroneously.pic.twitter.com/Havfr84W84

1110637970036609024.text:
4/ CMC has data integrity issues. Reliance on them holds back the industry.

Pro investors need a) custody solutions, b) regulatory clarity, and c) reliable markets data if they're to enter the space en masse.

CMC is the current standard for c.

But much of their data is wrong.pic.twitter.com/YqtAJU5hzx

1110637969415774208.text:
3/ The question for us is simple:

Should the industry continue to trust and promote CMC because it was first? Or should we begin holding them to account for some of their  practices?

We'd argue the latter.

1110637968665075712.text:
2/ First, we should acknowledge the tremendous job CMC has done over the years. They were:

+ contrarian and right about the long-tail of crypto assets
+ a best-in-class data provider wrt exchange and asset coverage
+ an open API provider (OCFX used them in 2017!)

Impressive co.

1110564655334899712.text:
